title: 103_s2267
content: The text chunk discusses the direct sale of excess property by Federal Prison Industries, allowing them to sell surplus items on the open market for the best available price. The proceeds from these sales will be deposited into the Treasury's Prison Industries Fund. The text discusses amending the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act to allow Federal Prison Industries to dispose of surplus property. Additionally, it amends transportation laws to exclude property described in section 4130 of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 2 amends Section 4126 of title 18, United States Code, regarding the determination of obligations and expenditures by Federal Prison Industries. It involves amending subsection (a) and redesignating subsection (f) as subsection (d). SEC. 3 amends the administration of Federal Prison Industries, allowing them to determine industrial operations in penal institutions. Commodities and services produced will be sold at market prices and meet government and industry standards. SEC. 4 addresses the production and acquisition of prison-made products and services. Sec. 4124 of title 18, United States Code is amended to regulate the production and acquisition of prison-made products, processes, and services by Federal Prison Industries for government institutions. Federal Prison Industries may produce products, processes, and services domestically that would otherwise be made offshore, with priority given to workshops for the blind or severely handicapped. They should also have the opportunity to participate as subcontractors in contracts for labor-intensive manufacturing segments. Federal Prison Industries can partner with private industry to produce goods and services domestically, focusing on labor-intensive processes that replace offshore production. They must ensure that this does not significantly compete with domestic labor or industry. Additionally, they are allowed to recycle materials for sale and engage in flood or disaster relief activities. Federal Prison Industries can produce goods and services for sale or donation to nonprofit organizations assisting in disaster relief programs. Items sold are exempt from certain laws, and inmates working on production are exempt from minimum wage requirements. Title 18, United States Code, is amended to update the item related to section 4124. Title 18, United States Code, is amended to update the item related to section 4124 regarding the production and acquisition of prison-made products, processes, and services. This section also addresses procurement. The amendment to Title 18, United States Code, includes a new section 4131 allowing Federal Prison Industries to use funds for procurement contracts related to goods for industrial operations without following standard federal procurement laws. The board of directors must establish procedures to ensure competitive procurement practices. Technical Amendment: The chapter analysis for chapter 307 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new item. "4131. Procurement."
